title-group.article-title: Effective elastic properties and stress distribution of 2D biaxial nonorthogonally braided composites

article-meta.aff: Key Laboratory for Liquid–Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University, Jinan, China

author-notes.corresp: Yuxi Jia, Professor, Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University, No. 17923, Jingshi Road, Jinan 250061, China Email: jia_yuxi@sdu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Due to the interlacement of tows, the architecture of braided composites is complex, especially for the nonorthogonal braid in which the tow has various cross sections along the towpath. The microscopic mechanical analysis is highly sensitive to the geometric architecture, which causes great difficulties for the research on material behavior of nonorthogonal braid. In this article, a finite element model has been proposed to investigate the effective elastic properties and stress distribution of 2D biaxial nonorthogonally braided composites. This research was conducted for two kinds of 2D biaxial braid, 1 × 1 and 2 × 2, using a parallelogram repeated unit cell that is suitable for the description of stress distribution under different load conditions. The differences between 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 in effective elastic properties and stress distribution were discussed. The effect of braid angle on the mechanical properties was also studied. The result reveals that 2 × 2 has greater in-plane Young’s modulus than 1 × 1 with the same tow, fiber volume ratio, and braid angle, although the situation of the out-plane Young’s modulus is on the contrary.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Compared with conventional unidirectional laminated composites, textile composites show higher wholeness, lesser fabrication cost, greater shear strength, and better impact resistance characteristics. They are widely applied in the aerospace, sports, automobile, and marine industries. Therefore, the development of textile fabric composites has been increasingly attracting scientists’ attention. The dominant forms of textiles are weaves, braids, and knits. This article focuses on the two typical delegates of 2D biaxial-braided composites: 1 × 1 braided composites (also called diamond-braided composites) and 2 × 2 braided composites (also called regular-braided composites).

Many researchers have developed different models for textile composites.1–5 Most of the previous work mainly focused on woven fabric composites because of their relative geometric simplicity. Ishikawa and Chou6–8 did a great deal of work for plain-woven composites. They proposed three kinds of 1D analytical models based on the classical laminated theory. Subsequently, many researchers developed 2D and 3D analytical models1–3 for woven composites on the basis of the previous work of Ishikawa and Chou. With full 3D modeling of the tow architecture, many researchers have developed finite element methods (FEMs) to analyze woven composites.1–4,9 The research methods used for woven composites have reference significance in the study of braided composites because of the geometric similarity between the two.1,4,5,10

In contrast to quite a lot of work on the woven composites, there are only a few studies on the braided composites.1,4,5 Naik et al.11 conducted an analytical and experimental study on the effects of braiding parameters on 2D triaxial-braided composites, using a volume averaging technique under isostrain assumption. Aggarwal et al.12,13 proposed an analytical model to predict the in-plane elastic constants and strength of 2D diamond-braided composites, using a combination of isostress and isostrain conditions. Quek et al.14 calculated the effective linear elastic stiffness of a 2D triaxial-flat-braided composite, and analyzed the effect of initial unintended microstructural imperfections on the calculated stiffness, using an analytical model. Huang and Ramakrishna15 presented a general methodology to analyze the stiffness and strength of 2D biaxial-woven or braided preform, using a bridging micromechanics model. Ayranci and Carey16 outlined an analytical study to predict the longitudinal elastic modulus of 2D tubular-braided composites, considering the effect of the curvature of the unit cell on tubular-braided composites.

Besides these analytical methods, the finite element approaches were also applied to study the 2D braided composites. D’Amato17 proposed a methodology for the structural analysis of braided composites through standard finite element codes at a microstructural level. Goyal et al.18 developed the 3D finite element micromechanics models to investigate the effect of various parameters on the effective engineering properties of the 2 × 2 braid. On the basis of this work, they further studied the stress concentrations and plastic behavior of 2 × 2 braided composites.19–21 Potluri et al.22,23 investigated the flexural and torsional properties of biaxial- and triaxial-braided composites through a modified laminate analysis and experiment, and then presented a finite element model for the nonorthogonally interlaced textile composites, including the sheared woven structure and braided structure. Fujihara et al.24 discussed the effect of braid angle on static and fatigue bending properties of braided laminated composites through experiment and FEM. Song et al.25 performed a finite element simulation of the compressive damage development process of 2D triaxial-braided carbon fiber composites. Lomov et al.26 investigated the full-field strain measurements on the surface of the sample for validation of meso-FE analysis of textile composites. Using this measurement, they supplied the details of the deformed state on the scale of individual yarns inside the textile. Tsai et al.27 proposed a parallelogram spring model for predicting the effective elastic properties of 2D triaxial-braided composites. This model treats each fiber tow as a curve composed of a series of springs with only axial rigidity. Iarve et al.28 proposed an independent mesh method for the 3D stress analysis in triaxial-braided composites. Nasu et al.29 clarified the deformation behavior and the relationship between thebraid angle and mechanical properties for the braided rectangular pipe through a three-point bending test and the FEM.

In summary, most of the previous studies focused on the effective mechanical properties of textile composites, but few efforts have been made to discuss the stress distribution in braided composites. Goyal and Whitcomb19 analyzed the stress concentration in 2 × 2 braided composites. Potluri and Manan23 discussed the stress distribution in 1 × 1 braided composites. On the basis of their work, this article presents a parallelogram repeated unit cell (RUC) model with the complex geometry of tow to investigate the stress distribution in both 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 braided composites under different load conditions, which is helpful for the damage analysis of mesoscale structure in 2D braided composites. The 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 braids are widely used as profile thin-walled preforms recently. Their mechanical properties are not identical, even if they are braided using the same tow and have the uniform tow volume fraction. Few papers investigated these differences. Therefore, a comparative analysis of their mechanical properties was carried out, which contributes to a thorough understanding of the effect of braided architecture on the mechanical properties.

sec.title: Geometric modeling
sec.p:
As seen in Figure 1, the overlapping pattern of tows changes over one tow in 1 × 1 and over two tows in 2 × 2. In this article, 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 are assumed to be braided with the same tow and have the same volume fraction of tow. The braid angle is measured from the axis of the braid to the axis of the bias tows, denoted by θ. The untwisted and orthogonal tows have a constant cross section which is assumed to be an ellipse with semimajor axis ‘a’ and semiminor axis ‘b’ in this article whereas nonorthogonal tows have variational cross sections. As seen in Figure 1, along the towpath of –θ tow, the cross sections at three locations selected at random are not identical. Therefore, the architecture of nonorthogonal tow is more complex. It should be noted that the section parallel to the other orientation tow, which is not the cross section, is unchanged along the towpath. It is an ellipse with semimajor axis ‘aθ’ and semiminor axis ‘bθ’, where aθ = a/sin (2θ), bθ = b. The tow is modeled through this ellipse along the towpath, using the quadratic surface of professional CAD software. Figure 1.
Microstructures of 2D biaxial-braided composites.

To match the section (aθ, bθ) of tow and the spacing between tows, the towpath is assumed to consist of ellipse arcs and straight lines, as represented by the curve AF in Figure 1, taking, for example, 1 × 1. To discuss stress distribution conveniently, ellipse arcs AB, CD, and EF are described as ‘overlapped parts’ (also called crossover regions5), and straight lines BC and DE are described as ‘joint parts’ (also called undulation regions5). In the overlapped part, the surface of the outer normal that points to the interlaced tow is called the ‘overlapped face’ (such as the upper surface of CD part and the lower surface of AB and EF parts), and the surface on the other side is called the ‘opposite face’ (such as the upper surface of AB and EF parts and the lower surface of CD part). The perpendicular distance between parallel tows is ‘s’ and the space between ellipses (aθ, bθ) is sθ = s/sin2θ. There is a finite gap between the overlapped tows, which was eliminated in most of the previous research. In this article, resin matrix filled in these overlapped regions has been modeled. The average gap between the overlapped tows is g = (h − 4b)/2, where ‘h’ is the height of the braided ply. The angle between straight line (BC, DE) and horizontal line is ‘α’ and is determined by ‘sθ’. The length ofthetowpath is lc≈2πbθ+4(aθ-bθ)+2sθ/cos α. The volume fraction of tows in composite is Vt = 4πablc/l2h sin (2θ), where ‘l’ is the length of the RUC and l = 4aθ + 2sθ. To ensure comparability between different architectures, all the models have the same volume fraction of tows ‘Vt’. Hence, the volume fraction of fibers ‘Vf’ in composite is identical,as Vf = VftVt, where ‘Vft’ is the volume fraction of fibers in tow. The geometric parameters are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Geometric parameters of model
a b Vft Vt Vf h
723.8 um 65 um 78.5% 63.66% 50% 300 um

In 2 × 2, lc≈2πbθ+4(aθ-bθ)+4aθ+4sθ/cosα, l = 8aθ + 4sθ, Vt = 8πablc/l2h sin (2θ). In order to have the same ‘Vt’ with 1 × 1, 2 × 2 has smaller ‘sθ’ and greater ‘α’ for the same braid angle. For 1 × 1 and 2 × 2, with the increase of braid angle, ‘sθ’ decreases.

Because of the regular array of tows in the textile composite, a RUC which is the minimum periodic structure is picked out and studied instead of the whole structure. Traditionally, a rectangular RUC is usually selected, denoted by ‘І’ in Figure 1. Tsai et al.27 proposed a parallelogram RUC that they found more appropriate than the rectangular RUC for 2D braided composites, denoted by ‘П’. But the continuity of stress at the interface between the adjacent RUCs is not proven. In this article, an RUC ‘Ш’ for which boundary is at the center of the tow is proposed. It guarantees the stress continuity and is suitable for the description of stress distribution.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p: Traditionally, the ‘homogeneous boundary conditions’ were used for the RUC of composites. But they are over-constrained and violate the boundary traction periodicity conditions. A unified periodical boundary condition presented by Xia et al.30 is adopted in this article. This condition overcomes the shortcomings of ‘homogeneous boundary conditions’. It not only fulfils the requirement of displacement periodicity and continuity but also ensures the stress distribution periodicity and continuity. It is presented as follows: (1) where ‘uj+j’ and ‘uj-j’ denote the displacements on a pair of opposite boundary surfaces (i + , i−), ‘i + ’ indicates that the outer normal of the surface is along the positive direction of Xi axis, ‘i−’ indicates that the outer normal is along the negative direction, and ‘j’ denotes the direction of the movement.

sec.title: Discretization
sec.p: Both tows and matrix were meshed with 8-node solid elements. The 2 × 2 braid has approximately 70,000 elements and the 1 × 1 braid has approximately 35,000 elements. They have the same mesh density because 2 × 2 RUC is twice as large as 1 × 1 RUC. This degree of discretization guarantees high fidelity of geometry and rational prediction of the effective elastic properties. The stress distribution will be more detailed if the element size is smaller. But the computation time and memory requirements increase significantly. For this degree of discretization, the stress state can be clearly depicted. Meshing accuracy was checked and validated. The tows are assumed to be perfectly bonded to the matrix. That was realized by a novel modeling approach for designing and constructing CAD-based composites unit cell presented by Sun et al.31 In the FEM, tow and matrix share common nodes at the interface.

sec.title: Constitutive relationship
sec.p:
The 411-350 epoxy resin and AS4 carbon fibers are used for the 2D biaxial-braided composites in this article. The epoxy resin matrix is an isotropic material. The fibers aretransversely isotropic materials and assumed to be arrayed in a hexagonal array in the tow, which makes the tow also be considered as transversely isotropic material after being homogenized. Hence, the tow has three principal directions of elasticity (1, 2, 3). The 2–3 coordinate plane is the isotropic plane and the tow has the greatest Young’s modulus in the direction of ‘1’ axis. The material parameters of tow and matrix were taken from Ref. 18 directly, as listed in Table 2. Braided composites are assumed to be anisotropic materials, and the constitutive relation is as follows: (2) where Cij denotes the stiffness coefficient matrix. To work out Cij, six individual deformations are imposed on the RUC, as shown in Figure 2. The mean stress and mean strain for each independent deformation are defined as: (3) (4) where ‘V’ denotes the volume of RUC, and ‘m’ denotes the number of elements in the RUC. Let [σ¯]= [σ¯11, σ¯22, σ¯33, σ¯23, σ¯31, σ¯12]T and [ε¯]=[ε¯11,ε¯22,ε¯33,ε¯23,ε¯31,ε¯12]T, Equation (2) is modified into the Equation (5) as follows: (5) Figure 2.
Six independent deformations. (a) In-plane uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction, (b) in-plane uniaxial tensile load along−θ direction, (c) out-plane uniaxial tensile load, (d) out-plane simple shear load along −θ direction, (e) in-plane simple shear load along −θ direction, and (f) in-plane simple shear load along + θ direction. Table 2.
Material properties for tow and matrix
Property Tow Resin
E11 (GPa) 204.4 3.1
E22 (GPa) 13.4 3.1
E33 (GPa) 13.4 3.1
ν12 0.21 0.35
ν23 0.29 0.35
ν13 0.21 0.35
G12 (GPa) 14.62 1.15
G23 (GPa) 5.33 1.15
G13 (GPa) 14.62 1.15

The effective stiffness coefficient matrix [C] can be worked out through the stress–strain relationship (Equation (5)), and the effective elastic properties can be obtained from the compliance matrix, which is the inverse transform of stiffness coefficient matrix. The road map is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Road map of numerical analysis.

sec.title: Equivalent laminate model
sec.p:
An equivalent laminate model presented by Goyal et al.18,19 is used to compare with the braid model. As shown in Figure 4, the laminate model has + θ, −θ, and matrix plies that correspond to the + θ tows, −θ tows, and matrix in the braided composites, respectively. This laminate model does not take the bending of tow into account. Through the comparative analysis, the effect of the crimp of tow on the effective elastic properties is discussed. Figure 4.
An equivalent laminate model.

sec.title: Stress distribution under different load conditions
sec.p: Due to the multilevel structure, the stress distribution in braided composites is very complex. Based on the high-fidelity modeling, the stress state under different load conditions is discussed. In order to have a comparative analysis, different models have the identical strain under the same load.

For the in-plane uniaxial tensile load, like the deformation (a) in Figure 2, the tow whose axis parallels the direction of load is the main bearing body and has greater stress than the other orientation tow. The contour maps for the six stress components in the main bearing tow are depicted in Figure 5. The 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 are identical in the stress distribution: the stress peaks appear at the joint parts, for the in-plane stress components it appears at the center of these parts, for the out-plane stress components it appears at the edge, and stress is greater at the surface than on the inside. But σ13 does not change from the inside to the outside.For the same strain, stress components in 1 × 1 are smaller than the ones in 2 × 2 except for σ33. The change of braid angle does not affect stress distribution but has influence on the stress value. For example, consider σ11 in 1 × 1, the value decreases with the increase of braid angle, as shown in Figure 6. Figure 5.
Six stress components distributions of + θ tows in ± 25° braided composites under the in-plane uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction (MPa). (a) 1 × 1 braided composites; (b) 2 × 2 braided composites. Figure 6.
Effects of braid angle on σ11 distributions of + θ tows in the 1 × 1 braided composites under the in-plane uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction (MPa).

For the in-plane simple shear load, like the deformation (e) as shown in Figure 2, + θ tow and –θ tow bear the same load. The stress distribution in 1 × 1 is consistent with the one in 2 × 2. The stress peaks appear at the joint part, and the edge of tow, expect the out-plane normal stress σ33. For example, considering the in-plane shear component σ12 in 1 × 1, with the increase of the braid angle, stress decreases, as depicted in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Effects of braid angle on σ12 distributions of −θ tows in the 1 × 1 braided composites under the in-plane simple shear load along + θ direction (MPa).

For the out-plane uniaxial tensile load, like the deformation (c) in Figure 2, + θ tow and –θ tow bear the same load. Different from the in-plane loads, the normal stress peaks appear at the overlapped parts, as shown in Figure 8. The shear stress peaks appear at the joint parts. The bottom panel is σ33 of 2 × 2 using the same stress contour with 1 × 1, and the 1 × 1 has greater stress σ33 than 2 × 2. Figure 8.
Six stress components distributions of + θ tows in ± 30° braided composites under the out-plane uniaxial tensile load (MPa).

From the earlier discussion, it can be seen that when the composites are under the in-plane load conditions, the interaction of ±θ tows mainly occurs at the joint parts, and when materials are under the out-plane load conditions, interaction occurs at the overlapped parts. The characteristic of braided structures determines the interaction pattern of the constituent materials.

sec.title: Effective elastic properties
sec.p:
‘Moduli’ of composites are macroscopic quantities that are determined by microscopic parameters. The effective elastic properties of different models are discussed in the following. As shown in Figure 9, the longitudinal Young’s modulus E11, decreases with increasing the braid angle and E11 of 2 × 2 is greater than that of 1 × 1. The transverse Young’s modulus E22 increases with the braid angle and E22 of 2 × 2 is also greater than that of 1 × 1. The effect of braid angle on the out-plane Young’s modulus E33 is not significant. But 2 × 2 has lower E33 than 1 × 1. The effective elastic properties of ±25° 2 × 2 braided composites are compared with the experimental results gained by Kelkar et al.,32 as listed in Table 3. The finite element results agree well with the experimental data. In this article, the shape of tow cross section is a simplification of the true shape. If the geometric modeling is closer to reality, the FEM results might have a better prediction. Figure 9.
Effects of braid angle on the Young’s modulus. Table 3.
Comparison between the FEM results and the experimental results
Modulus FEM results of the authors ± 25° Experimental results in Ref. [32]
±24.52° ±25.05° ±25.95°
E11 (GPa) 64.96 71.33 68.52 63.71
E22 (GPa) 11.57
E33 (GPa) 7.43
υ12 0.96 1.22 1.17 1.16
υ23 0.33
υ13 −0.01
G12 (GPa) 18.29
G23 (GPa) 2.27
G13 (GPa) 3.09

With the decrease of braid angle, the axes of tows are inclined to the longitudinal direction of braid and tows supply more deformation resistance in this direction, which results in the increase of Young’s modulus E11. At the same time, the tows are away from the transverse direction and the Young’s modulus E22 decreases.

The differences of effective mechanical properties between 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 can be proved using the analytical method presented by Quek et al.14 The equivalent laminate model that does not take the bending of tow into account is introduced to explain these differences, as depicted in Figure 4. The in-plane modulus of equivalent laminate is greater than that of the braid model and the out-plane modulus is smaller, as shown in Figure 9. The tow is considered to be the transversely isotropic material and has the greatest Young’s modulus in the direction of ‘1’ axis. In the equivalent laminate, the direction of ‘1’ axis does not change and is always parallel to the braid plane. In the braid model, the bending of tow leads to the change of the materials’ direction along the towpath. With the increase of ‘α,’ the joint part of tow reduces the contribution to the in-plane modulus and supplies more deformation resistance in the out-plane direction. Although the joint part in 1 × 1 has smaller ‘α’ than the one in 2 × 2, 1 × 1 has more joint parts than 2 × 2 for the same horizontal length. Therefore, 1 × 1 has lower in-plane modulus and greater out-plane modulus. It can be inferred from the results that, for the 2D biaxial-braided composites: the upper limit of in-plane moduli and lower limit of out-plane moduli are determined by the equivalent laminate model; and the lower limit of in-plane moduli and upper limit of out-plane moduli are determined by 1 × 1 model.
Succedent analysis of stress concentrations further interprets the differences between 1 × 1 and 2 × 2.

sec.title: Stress concentrations in 1 × 1 and 2 × 2 braided composites
sec.p:
Stress contours only supply partial information about stress distribution (on the surface or a certain cross section). To depict stress everywhere, the stress and volume of every element are counted. All the elements are sequenced according to their stress and the cumulative sum of their volumes are calculated. Therefore, what percentage of the tow exceeds a certain stress level can be determined. The ratio of volume is introduced as a parameter depicting the stress distribution. For example, consider ±25° braided composites under uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction, the relation between σ11 and volume ratio in + θ tow is depicted in Figure 10. The three perpendicular lines denote the mean stress of 1 × 1, 2 × 2, and laminate, respectively, which are obtained from Equation (3). The stress in 1 × 1 is smaller than that in 2 × 2. It is consistent with the preceding conclusion that 1 × 1 has lower in-plane Young’s modulus than 2 × 2. For 2D biaxial-braided composites, the lower limit of mean stress is determined by 1 × 1 and the upper limit is determined by the laminate model. Figure 10.
Relations between σ11 and volume ratio in + θ tows under the uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction.

As depicted in Figure 10, the stress peak is much larger than the mean stress. This results in stress concentration in braided composites. To compare the stress concentrations between 1 × 1 and 2 × 2, the abscissa is nondimensionalized, as shown in Figure 11. The relation curve, which is more inclined to the horizontal line implies that the deviation of the stress peak from the mean stress is greater and the stress concentration is more severe. In Figure 11(c), for example, ‘A’ represents that the stress is 1.03 times the mean stress, ‘B’ and ‘C’ are the corresponding volume ratios for 2 × 2 (72%) and 1 × 1 (90%), respectively. In 2 × 2, there are 28% elements for which stress is greater than 1.03 times mean stress, whereas in 1 × 1 this is 10%. The relation curve of 2 × 2 is more inclined to the horizontal line.For a certain abscissa value that can be considered as the criterion of stress concentration, 2 × 2 has moreelements with stress concentration than 1 × 1. Therefore, the stress concentration caused by 2 × 2 is more severe than that caused by 1 × 1 under the uniaxial tensile load. For example, consider 1 × 1: the effect of braid angle on the stress concentration is shown in Figure 12. The results reveal that with the decrease of braid angle, the stress concentrations get more severe. The same situation also occurs in the 2 × 2 braided composites. Whereas under the out-plane uniaxial tensile load, the stress concentration in 1 × 1 is more severe than that in 2 × 2, as shown in Figure 13. It is consistent with the effect of braided structure on equivalent elastic modulus (E33 of 1 × 1 is greater than that of 2 × 2). Under this load condition, the effect of braid angle on the stress concentration is not significant. Figure 11.
Relations between the stress σ11 to the mean stress ratio and the volume ratio in + θ tow under the uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction. (a) ± 25° braided composites, (b) ± 30° braided composites, (c) ± 35° braided composites, and (d) ± 40° braided composites. Figure 12.
Effects of braid angle on the stress concentration for the 1 × 1 braided composites under the uniaxial tensile load along + θ direction. Figure 13.
Relations between the stress σ33 to the mean stress ratio and the volume ratio under the out-plane uniaxial tensile load. (a) ± 25° braided composites; (b) ± 30° braided composites; (c) ± 35° braided composites; (d) ± 40° braided composites.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: For 2D biaxial-braided composites: under the in-plane load, the stress peak appears at the joint parts; under the out-plane load, the normal stress peak appears at the overlapped parts and the shear stress peak appears at the joint parts; the longitudinal Young’s modulus decreases but the transverse Young’s modulus increases with increasing braid angle; and the stress concentration gets more severe with the decrease of braid angle.

The in-plane Young’s modulus of 2 × 2 is greater than that of 1 × 1 with the same tow, fiber volume ratio, and braid angle. The situation of the out-plane Young’s modulus is on the contrary. Under the in-plane uniaxial tensile load, the stress concentration of 2 × 2 is more severe than that of 1 × 1 with the same strain. Whereas under the out-plane uniaxial tensile load, the stress concentration in 1 × 1 is more severe than that in 2 × 2.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work is supported by the Natural Science Foundation of China (50973056) and Shandong Province (JQ201016) and the National Basic Research Program of China (2010CB631102).
